div.p: Cuckolds-Haven: OR, AN ALDERMAN No Conjurer. A FARCE. Acted at the QUEEN'S THEATRE in Dorset Garden.
LONDON, Printed for J. H. and are to be sold by Edward Poole, next door to the Fleece Tavern in Cornhill. 1685.

div.head: TO THE HONOURABLE COLONEL Edmund Ashton.
div.p:
AS you will find the following Scenes drawn from the Stores of that great Master Ben, I hope you will think the Contrivance no ill Imitation: That they had no better Success on the Stage, was for this Reason: The principal Part (on which the Diversion depended) was, by Accident, disappointed of Mr. Nokes's Performance, for whom it was design'd, and only proper; which caus'd a Retrenchment of whole Scenes in the Action, that are in this Copy inserted. As it here lies
together, if the Plot be not too regular for Farce, and ought not rather to have been call'd Comedy, I dare trust the Reader for the rest. Notwithstanding all the Disadvantages in its Appearance on the Stage, you were pleased, Sir, to discover some Beauties through the Cloud. However, I am not so much concern'd for a Work of this Nature, as to impose the Protection of it upon you. My Ambition in this Address, is, to owne my good fortune in your Acquaintance, and Advantages from thence, as to Nobler Species of Poetry. I speak not with relation to any Essays of my own, but for improvement of my Skill in the best Latin Poets. When Ben Johnson was inform'd, that a certain Person had done him Injury, he cry'd out with Indignation, I made the Ingrateful Man understand Horace. Obligations of this kind, indeed, are unvaluable. I presume (Sir) I could before pretend to a Grammarians, or Commentators knowledge; but this was understanding like a Dutchman:

lg.l: From whom, the Author's more obscure become,
The Fogs of Holland cloud the Wit of Rome;
While these the Vehicle of Words essay,
The subtle Spirit flies unseen away.

div.p: They understood the Words, but you the Poet. Your Judgment does not terminate in what is express'd, but takes in the whole Scope of Fancy, and feels the flame of the Poet, while he labour'd with Inspiration. In short (Sir) you make their very Spirit visible; and with piercing sight discover those Beauties, which their Art threw off to such distance, that they were not discern'd by Vulgar Eyes. The World must allow me to pay this Acknowledgment: It is what I heard own'd (while a Stranger to you) by a * * E. of Roscommon. first-rate Judge, as well as Poet; he that was at once the Horace and Mecaenas of our Age. know, Sir, you will pardon me, if on mention of that Noble Person, I stain this Paper with a Tear.

lg.l: Multis ille bonis flebilis Occidit,
Nulli flebilior quam Tibi -------

div.p:
Of many Obligations that endear his Memory to me, the Opportunity of your Acquaintance was not the least; while I have heard you discant together on your beloved Authours, Time seem'd to me to be revolv'd, and I thought my self in the Court of Augustus. I think the Nation is duly grateful for what he has transplanted from their Language, though sparing of those Favours. We likewise know, Sir, that you have not fate down with the bare knowledge of those ancient Roman Treasures, without giving some parts of them the English Stamp. And to hoard them in Secresy, is injury to your Country. It was always thought the Perfection of an Honourable person, to be an Accomplisht Courtier, Souldier, and Scholar. All which Capacities are (Sir) without Complement, ascrib'd to You. Nor may we omit, that Justice, Courtesie, and Condescention, which (in relation to Inferiours) compleat
the Character of a Gentleman. As a just Respect on these Worthy Accounts is rendred to you by all Persons, it is by none more sincerely paid, than by,

closer.signed: Your most Humble Servant, and Admirer, N. TATE.

lg.l: WE own, nor to confess it are asham'd, (fram'd.
That from tough Ben's Remains, this Piece was
But if Embellishments of Vanity
And Vice, are here improv'd to a degree
Beyond the Characters that Master drew,
We must the Ladies thank for that, and you,
So far above what Johnson's Age e'er knew.
Our Scene's compact, and if it be not witty,
You must consider, Sirs, 'tis laid i'th' City.
Where yet we shall present one Sparkish Citt,
Who Drinks, Whores, Dresses, which I think is Wit;
Or, Mercy on three parts of this good Pit.
Lewdness and Dress must, by the Criticks Pardon,
Be Wit, or 'gad ye ruine Covent-Garden.
But Sense, or Nonsense, is to us all one,
Our Trinculo and Trapp'lin were undone,
When Lime's more Farcy Monarchy begun.
Oh! Were this Frantick Nations Woes too few,
But we must have both Dam and Devil too?
First, with the Old Serpent plagu'd of Associations,
And since, with viler Spawn of Declarations:
Whose poyson such Distraction cou'd create,
That Scyth-men listed to Mow down the State.
But now the Monster has her final Rout,
The very Dregs of Treason's Tap are out:
This Triumph then, with Just Applause be given
To Caesar's Conduct, and assisting Heaven.
Sense now shall flourish, Discord be no more,
For Wit and Peace are Caesar's to restore.

list.label: Alderman Touchstone, intended for Mr. Nokes,
Golding, his Sober Servant,
Quick-silver, his Debauch'd Servant,
Security, a Bawd and Usurer,
Sir Petronell Flash,
Captain Seagull,
Mr. Bramble, a Lawyer,
Mrs. Touchstòne,
Girtred, her Daughter, an Affected Cittess, Married and cozen'd by Sir Petr. Flash.
Mildred, the Sober Daughter,
Security's Wife,
Syndefie, Punk to Quicksilver.
Servants and Sailers.

div.head: A NEW FARCE, CALL'D Cuckolds-Haven. ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.stage: Touchstone's Shop at the farther End; Golding walking short turns before it. Touchstone with Accounts in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: UPon Mortgage of his whole Estate remains due to his Lordship 300 l. this comes of Prodigality, of his Lordships Stewards towards a Purchace for himself 5000. There's the fruits of Industry— At Interest for Mrs. Procure-well 1200. There's Industry again— Lent, Receiv'd, Receipts, Receipts, Disbursements, Bonds, bonds, Judgments, &c. Well, we Marry'd Citizens had need of strong Heads to support what is put upon'em; our greatest Care is, to look after them that should take the Care off our Hands. I must in and settle these Accounts before—
sp.stage: [As he is going in, Quick-silver enters upon him and drives him backward.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Alack! alack, Sir! sincerely, I did not think of your Worship.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou insolent Varlet! What? stumble upon the very Face of Authority? Do'it thou behold no Terrour in this overture? Is this natural Type of Reverence, and this Emblem of the Cities Honour, but Cyphers with you? ha!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Peradventure, Sir—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I will not be peradventured, Sir; Answer me directly. What loose Action are you now bound for? what Comrades are you to meet? who gives the Supper? and where's the Rendezvouz? I will have an Account of all these in a Breath, in a Sentence, in one Word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Indeed, and in very good sober Truth, Sir—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Indeed, and in very good sober Truth, Sir!— behind my back thou wilt swear faster than a French Foot-Boy, and talk more Baudy than a Midwife.— I tell thee, Sirrah, I am thy natural Lord and Master, William Touchstone, Goldsmith and Alderman of London, an Alderman, Sirrah, Alderman; I will likewise make thee understand that thou art my indented Servant, Francis Quick-silver.— Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Surely I am your bounden and most faithful—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Without Preamble, I will know what Diversion you are now a running to.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Surely one may use his Recreation with his Master's Profit.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Servants Recreations are seldom with their Master's Profit: --- Work upon that now—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Surely I was but going to a Funeral Sermon, Sir,— of a dear Friend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Say'st thou so— I protest I was to blame for chiding thee— dear Francis, I ask thy Pardon and am sorry for thy Friend with all my heart— But, Sirrah, seeing is believing, shew me your Sermon-Book, produce your Shorthand-Book, quickly I say.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Let me see't.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Sincerely, I shall come too late, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Let me see't I say— what is here? Sol, la! me, fa! sol, sol, --- what has this to do here?— With a Stone at the Gate, and a handsom young Wench to rub my bald Pate.— Why, thou Pagan Rogue: Thou hast more Tricks with thee than an Irish Run-a-way with seven years Improvement in the West-Indies. I will see further what Rigging you have about; off with that Cloak of Iniquity, where are you?
sp.stage: [Quick-silver dodges about him, at last Touchstone pulls off his Cloak and discovers Flutes, Swords, Pumps, Racks, Dancing Shoes, &c. girded round him.
sp.p: Hey-day, hey-day! what a Composition is here! Thou hast more Trangams about thee than a Hocus Pocus, or the Wonderful Fish that came Arm'd against Turk and Pope.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou shameless Varlet, do'st thou deride me too? do'st thou laugh at thy lawful Master, contrary to thy Indentures? I will make thee, Sirrah, at Noon-day for Pennance, to walk in this Equipage from Leaden-Hall to Ludgate.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I will as soon serve a Prenticeship to every Cuckold betwixt Leaden-Hall and Ludgate, by this Light. What a Plague, Sir, I am a Gentleman, tho a younger Brother, and your Worships Servant.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do'st thou Swear, Rake-hell? thy Father was an honest Tradesman.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
But my Mother was a Gentlewoman, and with your favour, Sir, I will swear by the Mothers side. Is it not for your Worships Advantage that I keep Company? I am entertain'd amongst Gallants, they call me Cousin Frank; right. I lend them Money; good. They spend it; very well. And when 'tis gon, must they not strive to get more? must not their Land fly? and to whom? shall not your Worship have the Refusal? How could Tradesmen
thrive if Gentlemen were not Unthrifts? how could Gentlemen be Unthrifts without Supplies for their Debauchery? Well, the City ought to consider me. I am now going to a Gaming-House; the Sparks fall to Play; I carry light Gold with me; Cousin Frank, say they, some Gold for Silver; I change gain by it: They lose the Gold and cry, Cousin Frank, Lend me some Silver; by which means—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay, the Rogue has Wit, that's certain; the Rogue has Wit— I cannot help loving the Dog— but, Sirrah, did I gain my Wealth by Ordinaries? no. By exchanging of Gold? no. By keeping Gallants Company? no. I hired me a little Shop, sought low, kept no Debt-Book, garnish'd my Shelves for want of Plate with good wholsom thrifty Sentences; as, Touchstone keep thy Shop, and thy Shop will keep thee; Light Gains, make heavy Purses; Be merry, and wise. And when I was Wiv'd having somthing to stick to, I had ever the Horn of Security before my Eyes; you all know the device of the Horn, where the young Fellow slips in at the Butt, and comes squeez'd out at the Buckall. Yet I grew up to this Dignity that you see here, and bear my Brows as high as my Neighbours; but thou— well, look to Accounts, your Father's Bond lyes for you, Seven hundred art thou run out of Cash.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I have proper Gentlemens words for't, and well drest! shall I deny a Gentleman that calls me Cousin Frank?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Which is Mr. Touchstone's Shop?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here, Sir. What lack you, Sir? what d'ye buy, Sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Look you there now! there's your Fellow Servant, do's he spark it? well, if he outlast not an hundred such crackling Bavins as thou art, Heav'n and Men neglect Industry— with me Boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Master, Sir Petronell Flash, presents his Service to you, and intends instantly to visit you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I understand you Boy: to Consummate Marriage with my Eldest Daughter, my Wive's Dilling, whom she longs to call Madam— Your Master shall find me most unwillingly ready, Boy.

There's another Affliction too; my Eldest Daughter is as Prodigal as my youngest Servant. She must be Ladify'd forfooth, take all her Dress from the Court, take Quality-Rambles, and keep Quality-Hours. Well, a piece of Land she has, her Grandmothers Gift, let her Sir Petronell flash out that: But as for my Substance, she that scorns me, as I am a Citizen and Alderman, shall never be the better for that; nor shall that be the worse for her— However— Golding, come hither, Golding— no, no, you Quick-Silver— I, I, Golding, Golding my outmost Care is for thee, and my only Trust is in thee, look to the Shop— Mr. Quick-Silver, look on the Brodigals Hog-trough in the Hangings within, I say, Consider them: think upon Husks: Husks— work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Husks in your Wittal's weazon; and a Million of Milstones to the Bargain. Here's Authority with a Horse Pox.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: For shame how you Talk.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And who shall say me nay? I will both Talk and Swear, I am a Gentleman, and may Swear by my Pedigree. Golding thou art yet ---- but I'll improve thee into a Man and a good Fellow, I will shew thee Company with Souls in them, Drink thee into good Blood.

lg.l: Good store of brisk Claret supplies ev'ry thing,
And the Man that is Drunk is as great as a King.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Away with your Ribaldry Play-house Morals.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I tell thee we will redeem, redeem the City's Honour, and shew there may be 'Prentices that are no Coxcombs. Shall our free Spirits be held in Bonds of Calf-skin, and subjected to a formal Beard and Chain?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do nothing, turn Gentleman and be Idle; the Curse of Man is Labour. Wilt thou walk here from Sun to Sun between two Pissing Posts, or stand with a bare Pate, driveling Nose, and Arms a-cross under a rotten Pent-house?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Away, you Prodigal Fool.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: That word again and thou art Immortal.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Thou Shuttle-Cock; Thou Gull of lew'd Companions; I see thee already in the Temple Rounds with half a Hat, thy Crevat the reversion of a Barber's Apron— soft, soft, unsheath that Iron, and I will make thee swallow it.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman, I'll get drunk incontinently, incontinently, grow Valiant, and beat thee.

sp.stage: Wynifred Security's Wife, and Clogg giving her a Letter.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: From your Admirer Madam, Sir Petronell Flash.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: And are you certain my Old Security did not see you take it in?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Pray think I understand my Office better.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: What an impudent Knight is this to continue addressing to me, and send me word the same time that he's going to be Marry'd, but for my sake and to prevent Suspicion: 'tis a scurvy sure way, and I could have studdy'd better. I'll hear no further from him.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: By your Beauties leave, Madam, I must presume to say you are not altogether so wise as true politick Wife would be; who being Marry'd to such a Nicumpoop (I speak it with my Master's peace) whose Face confesses him what you ought to make him), that you will out of conscientious scruple, defraud a poor Old Gentleman of what he longs for, and makes it his whole studdy to compass only a Modish Title; could he but write Cuckold he has his Ends; for look you—

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: What means the Varlet? why thou know'st the golden Fruit was never watcht so, as my Old Dragon watches me.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Why, there you find his worshipful Ambition, the Top of it, the very forked Top. Why should he keep you thus mur'd up in a back Room, allow you ne'er a Casement to the Streets, for fear of ingendring by the Eyes, forbid you Paper, Pen and Ink like Rats-bane, search your half Pint of Sack, least a Letter should be sunk in it? why all this Confinement but to make Men covet you the more?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: I grant it indeed the only Method that cou'd seduce me, and bring upon his head what most he fears.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Will you make benefit of Time and Truth? I am set over you, employ'd to watch your Steps, your Looks, your very Breathings, and report them to him, now if you will be a modish right sweet Mistress, we'll make a Cokes of this wise Master, an absolute fine Cokes, quite disappoint the Care and Industry of such a solemn and effectual Ass, an Ass to such good purpose as we'll make him.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: I am, 'tis true, my Master's man, but my Mistresses slave, the Servant of her Pleasures and sweet Turns, and know all Points that will conduce to them. I will contrive it so that you shall go to Park, to Plays, to Feasts and Masquerades, take care you shall have such Rigging Sails, and Trim as handsome Vessels shou'd put forth with, I'll choose you Confidents, and Lovers, convey your Letters, fetch you Answers, with all other Offices requisite to youthful Blood and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: This is most strange.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: And for Variety, at times (though I am not of Symmetry and Complexion to boast a Soveraignty over Ladies hearts, like some of my sphere) yet I can do, my sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Dear, delicate Madam, I am your little Paraquit, your Sparrow, your Shock, your Pugg, your Squirrel.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Impudent Slave! what can the Varlet mean by this Presumption? ----- Oh, I havé found it out, and was most dull not to conceive it before; My jealous Husband put him on this Practice— Where are you, Sir? for I know you hear me; come from your peeping Corner; spare your self a little from your Watch to applaud your Groom here, that so well follows your Instructions.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Where is my little Bunting? why how now, Bird? what, in a Pett? I Prithee what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Very well, you are a Stranger to the Plot, I warrant you? did not set your Vassal here to tempt your innocent Wife with most uncivil Language and Action?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: I sweat, I sweat.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I understand thee not, my Goldfinch.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Sir, the Essex Squire has been thrice here since you went out, he'll Mortgage to his Uncle, unless you find him instantly.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That must not be— What were you saying, Chick?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Durst he presume to mention Love to me without Directions from you?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: To mention Love to thee, Bunting? Conspire against my Honour?— What wert thou saying, Clogg? is there any Danger of our missing of the Mortgage— The Varlet durst not do't, my Lark. What? mention Lewdness to thee? any thing that pointed towards Cuckolds Row?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: As if you were not planted on the Stairs, or behind the Hangings— I am sure 'twas your Direction.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Thou shalt see, Bird, how I directed him,
O thou most manifest Villain! Thou Fiend Apparent! Thou declar'd Hell-hound!

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Knave, Rascal, Traitor, have I found you? what, upon your first point of Trust and Charge? the very Week of your Probation?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Some Moderation, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Have I for this conferr'd all Offices upon thee, made thee my Clerk, Wardrobe Man, Caterer, Cook, Butler, Steward, and what transcends all these, my Wife-watcher?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: But tell me, Cue; where were you all the while?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: At Councel Bramble's, Bird, drawing up of a Judgment.— There is one blow more for exercise— You see, my Lark, how I directed him.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Would you had done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: O Bird, what Blessings follow Industry, no less than three Forfeitures this Morning.— One more to put you in mind of the last? you are pamper'd with your whole Pitchard a day, I shall reduce you to a Sprat, Rogue. Are you tentiginous? ha!

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: I shall expire --- dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And what'is all this care and toil of mine for, but to enrich thee, Bird? Six Flanders Mares to your Coach, that's your Proportion. I do hunger and thirst to do the good, Bird.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Why am I then confin'd to one dark Room?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: For thy good still, Bird, and beside, to please thee thou shalt have thy Cage new Painted. There's conceit for thee. Turn me loose to the wittiest of 'em, and to the wisest too. What Trade like mine of Usury? All others complain of Inconvenience. The Merchant says, Traffick is subject to Incertainty and Loss; let them keep their Goods on dry Land with a Vengeance. Besides, their Gains are unconscionable, two for one, or so; whereas I in my Lending of Money am content with moderate Profit, 30 or 40 in the 100, so I may have it with Quietness, and no Hazzard.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Thy Godfathers were in the right; Cue, thou deserv'st thy Name.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p:
One Prays for a Westwardly Wind to carry his Ship out, another for an Eastwardly to bring his home; and at every shaking of a Leaf he falls into an Ague. The Farmer is ever at odds with the weather, sometimes the Clouds are barren, their Harvests are too thin; sometimes the Season is too fruitful, and Corn will bear no Price; whereas we that Trade only in Money, are
pleas'd with all Weathers; so the Sun and Moon stand not still, but make up Days, Months, and Years.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: O Sir, Mr. Francis Quick-silver's below.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Bring him up, dear Charge, I do hunger and thirst to do him good. ---- To thy Chamber, my dear Turtle.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Let it be the Street Room this time, Cue.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: It shall be the back Room, I have Sworn it in the violence of my Affection to thee.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: One pair of Stairs then.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Two, Bird, Two. Thou seest my Love in keeping thee so close, it shews thou art my Jewel— In my sight still?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And how fares my Old Dad? does he digest Iniquity well still? and has he seen my running Gelding drest to day? O, my dear Syndefie, that Time were half so fleet, my wisht Enfranchisement would soon arrive.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Ah Frank, you wish you know not what! your Master's Wealth and Trust supports you now, but when that Term's expir'd—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why then I'll conjure Money to my Pockets, tho she were fled and dead, I'd raise her with Aqua vitae out of old Hogsheads; while there are Lees of Wine or Dregs of Beer, I'll never want her; Coyn her out of Cobwebs; raise Wool upon Eggshels, make Grass grow upon Marrow-bones, but I will make her come.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Come, you may yet provide a Stock for Traffick against your time expires.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool Syn. Traffick! shall I, who am the Flower of City Wits, turn Paltry Merchant, and trust my Estate to a Hogs-trough? what are Ships but Tennis Balls for the Winds to play withal? footra for dull Preferments of the City. I will to Court Syn.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: What Winds or Seas have Hazard like—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ah Pox! and who taught you this Morality?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Long of this Witty Age, Mr. Francis, and your Mercurial Conversation.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well said Old Dad, Thou Father of Destruction. I am bringing more Widgeons into thy Usurious Nets. Claw me, claw thee, runs through Court and Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Right, my subtle Quick. I do therefore hunger and thirst to do thee good. ----- But what new Game hast thousprung, my nimble Francis; for I do hunger and thirst to do thee good?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A certain Knight of my Acquaintance—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I hunger and thirst to do him good.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Has present Occasion for twelve Hundred Guinneys: Sir Petronell Flash by Name.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How? that Bankrupt Prodigal, I renonnce him and his Wants.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: That is betwixt you and I, Dad: but this Day he Marries my Master's eldest Daughter, and—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Bring me to him instantly, I hunger and thirst to do him good, come bring me to him— You were tentiginous, Rogue, were you?

sp.stage: Girfred, Mildred, Poldavie with a French Mantoa under his Arm, Girfred's Maid.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: For the Passion of Patience, look if Sir Petronell approach; that sweet, that fine, that Alamode, that— for Loves sake tell me if he come— O Sister Mill, tho my Father be a Paltry Tradesman, yet I must be a Lady, and I will be a Lady, and I thank my Stars, my Mother must call me Madam— does he come, off with this scandalous Gown for shame, let not my Knight take in this vile City cut at any rate— does he come?— tear it, Pox on't, tear't off— Thus while she sleeps, I sorrow for her sake— What a dull English Animal art thou to keep me an Age in torment? tear it off, I say.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Lord, Sister, with what disdain do you put off your City Tire? what pains you take to make your self Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Lord, Sister Mill, that you will be pretending to Gallantry and Dress with that mechanick Soul of yours! how often have I told you that you have no Genius for these things? How should you understand Mien or bon Grace, the Brillian and Negligence of a Court Carriage, the belle conceit of a Fan, and the Esprit of a Fontnage? I have studdy'd these, things, and have fancy to reach the Meridian of them.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: To reach the Meridian of Folly, you mean, Sister.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Your Ambition, Sister, aspires no higher than to Marry a Common-Council-Man, and a Crape Gown with a filthy English Cut may serve your turn: but I must be a Lady. I like the humour of some City Dames well, to eat Cherries at an Angel a Pound pretty well: to die Scarlet black Tolerable: to line their Coachès with Velvet indifferent; but for a thousand other Niceties they have no Fancy: they are my Aversion as I hope to be a Lady ----- Is he not come yet? Lord, what a long Knight 'tis? And ever she cry'd shoot home, shoot home ---- yet I have known à longer ----

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Well, Birds that scorn their Nest before their Plumes are grown ----

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Still at your reprimands? Thou art more dull and troublesome than Bow-Bell. When I am a Lady, I'll pray for thy Conversion to Sense; nay, I'll vouchsafe to call thee Sister Mill; for though thou art not like to be a Lady, yet 'tis possible thou may'st be sav'd as soon as I ---- not come yet? ---- and ever and anon, she doubled in her Song ----- Liberty, Liberty. Now Monsieur Poldavie for your Reputation; come, fit it on.

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: Me sal please you Madam assurement,

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: There's mettle for you! well, there's more Soul in one French Taylor, than in a whole Company of our Train'd-Bands. Page, let me have the French Song, it will help off this fatigue of Dressing.

lg.head: She.
lg.l: THe Wise believe that I love none,
And some that I love All;
While none can call my heart his Own,
Each Portion is so small.

lg.head: He.
lg.l: Some say, I for Olinda dye;
My Breast so fierce a Passion warms;
Most think my hour is not so nigh,
But ah! They little know her Charms.

lg.head: She.
lg.l: My Heart's the Weather-cock of Love,
Which ev'ry Sigh can turn;
And ev'ry am'rous Breath can move,
But Nothing make it burn.

lg.head: He.
lg.l: My Heart is Love's meer Tennis-Ball,
Here tost, there bandy'd up and down;
But in good Hands, if once it fall,
'Tis lodg'd, 'tis then for ever gon.

sp.stage: [Poldavie the mean time fits on her Mantoa, and her Woman puts on her Head-Tire.
sp.p: And is this Alamode upon your Honour, Monsieur?

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: Ver fine, Madam; here it be close, here it be stiff, here it be Capacity, and will keep your Tighs so cool. Here vas de faut in your Body, Madam; but mee have rectify dat defect with de effect of my steel Instrument; my steel Instrument, Madam, have one Eye, but can ver well see to rectify de imperfections in de Ladies Proportions, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And how must I bear my Hands now? light.

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: Ouy, Madam, now you be de Court fashoon, you must all ting light, tread light, and fall light— bon amy! dat be de Court Ambla.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Has the Court never a Trott, Monsieur?

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: No Trotta, no Trōtt, but de false Gallopa, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: An' thou hadst been an English Tire-woman, I should have beaten thee; for I could learn another Story of Fontanges.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The Knight is come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Is my Knight come? where's my Fan now? Sister, do my Cheeks look well? give me a little Box o'th' Ear, to fetch the Colour into them. So, so ---- O dearest Dear! How does my Errant Knight?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: For shame, with more Modesty.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Modesty! why? I am no Citizen now: Modesty! am not I to be Marry'd? you had best keep me Modest when I am a Lady; the way of ---- is a la negligence, is't not my Hero?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Assurance there is necessary, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: But why came you no sooner, Knight?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A most important—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And who were you with?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A true—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And was your Wine good?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: If you—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And were your Company mad enough? for I must have you very lewd; 'tis Alamode and great. Well, there is nothing can spoil our Happiness, but your being too fond of me; fondness in a Husband is a mechanick thing. I hope therefore you'll prove wild, to justifie your Quality.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I shall endeavour on my part, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Welcom, my honorable Guest; and when must this Marriage affair be dispatcht?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I come now, Madam, to consummate it; If Mr. Alderman pleases, you may this Morning call a poor Knight Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And my Daughter Madam; what an Air is there! how well her Dress and Quality becomes her!
Look here, Master Touchstone, and weep your Eyes blind for Joy; would you imagine this to be your Daughter? for my part, I scarce can. What, no respect to her Ladiship?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Sir Knight, you are welcom to her Body; as for the rest, I am not unwilling to forego it; because it is not in my Power to keep it from you. There I think I am civil to you. Seven hundred Pound purchase of
Land her Grandmother left her, is yours; Her self (as her Mother's Gift) is yours; but if you expect any thing from me, know, that my Hand Eyes open together; I do not give blindly ---- Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sir, You mistrust my Means; I hope, I am a Knight.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sir, what I do not know, I must be bold to say I am ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Nay, I can answer for his being a Knight; I know where he had the Money to pay his Fees. And so might you have been a Knight, an' you had not been an Afs; had I thought you wou'd not have been Knighted, I would have dub'd you my self— but as for your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: I Mother, I must be a Lady anon, and by your leave, Mother, (I speak it not without my Duty, but only in right of my Husband) I must take place of you, Mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: That you shall, Lady-Daughter; and have a Coach too, as well as I.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And, by your leave, Mother, (I speak it not without my Duty, but only in right of my Husband) my Coach-Horses must take the Wall of your Coach-Horses.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Come, come, the Day wears apace; I love to have a scurvy Business soon over— There I think I was civil again— d'ye hear, Sir, how you will use this Daughter of mine, I know not; and how she will deserve to be us'd, I know less than t'other: But I must tell you, Sir, that for your sake she has refus'd known honest Men, well money'd, better traded, best reputed ---- Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Citizens, ma soy, beastly Citizen, sweet Knight, as soon as ever we are Marry'd, take me to thy mercy out of this miserable City, from the scent of Sea-coal, and the hearing of Bow-Bell; let us but Marry a little, and then down with me, down with me immediately.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

sp.stage: A Chair, Coat, Perewigg, and Band. After a confused manner, the Waits, Drums, Trumpets, saluting the Bridegroom; Enter Touchstone, in his Night Gown and Cap.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: HEre's a Noise with a Vengeance, as if a Pope were Roasting with Cats in his Belly. Why, my House has been made a Tavern this Night; but my comfort is, the Reckoning falls to my. Wife's Charge. Our Bellies have stow'd more sorts of Provision than Noah's Ark: 'Tis our City's fault, which, because we do it but seldom, we do it the more sinfully.— Hey! Quick-silver— Here's no being heard without a Speaking Trumpet— Quick-silver, I say, Mr. Francis Quick-silver.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Here, Sir. Uck!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Most worshipful Sir, will your important Affairs give you leave to Dress me?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I should leave any Business to serve you, Sir; though I were fast asleep. Uck!
sp.stage: [He puts on his Coat wrong, and Buttons it behind.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Foh, Sirrah! how you stink of Wine.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Would you desire a better smell, Sir? Uck! uck!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The Drunken Hiccough too, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis but the coldness of my Stomach, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What, have you the Cause natural for it? The Wedding Night could not moisten your Throat sufficiently, but the Morning too must rain her Dews upon you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: An' please you, Sir, we did but drink to the coming off of the Knightly Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To the coming off on him?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I, Sir, we drank to his coming on when we went to Bed, and now we are up, we must drink to his coming off; That's the chief Honour of a Souldier, Sir; and therefore we must drink so much the more to it. Uck!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A very Capital Reason. I believe your Logick must be forc't anon to make three Silver Tankards out of two.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Knight's Men are still on their Knees at it; and because 'tis for your Credit, Sir, I would be Ioth to flinch.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, to'em again: you are one of the separated Crew, one of my Wife's Faction.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Of the sure side, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And of my young Ladies, with whom, and her great Match, I will have nothing to do.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, Sir, now I will go keep my Credit with 'em, an' please you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: By any means, Sir, I beseech you, lay one Cup of Sack more upon your cold Stomach ---- but have a care, Sirrah, your Head will be turn'd presently, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Your Worship's Head is turn'd already, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What's that, Rogue? ha! Drunk for my Credit, quoth-a? 'tis a sprightly Knave this. I have two Daughters just like my two Servants; one has Grace, and no Wit; the other Wit, and no Grace; There's my Wife has neither. Well, Mr. Alderman, thy Preferment is thy Comfort; and in that Consideration—
sp.stage: [Looks in the Glass, and sees himself wrong drest.
sp.p: What's here now? what a prophane Varlet is this, not to know the right side of an Alderman?— he said my Head was turn'd indeed. Golding, Golding.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here, Sir; what does your Worship want?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Come, Dress me, Golding.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Undress you, Sir, you mean?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: There's a piece of Conceit too: well, every thing must have a beginning ---- How now Mil?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: How fare you, Sir, this Morning? has not the Noise disturb'd you? it was my Mother's humour.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So now, here's all the sober parcel my Family can shew; the rest of my House are giddy, the very Stairs and Walls stagger ---- thy Mother, Mil, has us'd me to Noise, I thank her. Let me see now, let me survey your two Physiognomies; some Resemblance upon my Honour: Golding, I can tell thee for thy comfort, thou wilt come to be an Alderman; I see by that thriving Sheeps-face of thine.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your Worship thinks too favourably of me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Come hither, Mil; what think'st thou of thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: As a Sister, Sir; I hope well.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I wou'd not give a Button for thy hopes of her, nor my own neither; but tell me what thou think'st of her?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am loth to think ill, Sir; and sorry that I cannot speak well.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Very good: and, Golding, how likest thou the Knight, Sir Flash? Does not the Elephant look big? They say, he has a Castle in the Country.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n the Elephant carry not his Castle on his Back, Sir; the best I can say of him is, that I know him not.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Golding, I commend thee, I approve thee, and I will make it appear that my Affection is strong to thee ---- My Wife has had her humour, and I will have mine. Dost thou see my Daughter there? she is not fair, not very fair, somewhat favourable like me ---- her Face, I must tell thee, has a great Blessing with it; that it will give thee no reason to suspect her ---- look you, thou art towardly, she is modest; thou art provident, she is careful ---- she's now Mine, give me thy Hand ---- she is now Thine; Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir, I had too much Honour in your Service;
But to make me your Son—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Is to get me a Grandson, I take it. Come, ye modest Fools, I must have you better acquainted: Lip her, slave, Lip her; what? dost thou pauze upon the Matter? why, there's thy Fellow-servant Francis, would have come over for the King with half this Encouragement.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I scarcely, Sir, durst trust my happiness.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay, I was never forward to meddle with any thing that I durst not, truth of it; let me see, Thou hast a kind of a serious leering look too; a little too much Modesty at present; but when thou art Marry'd I warrant thou wilt— ha!— Thou wilt— what was I a going to say now— go, get you gone, you little tynie Rogues; get you gone together.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Halloa, you pamper'd Jades of Asia.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Why, how now, Sirrah? what vein is this? ha!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Who cries on Murder? Lady, was it you?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, Sirrah, you are past your drunker Hiccough now, I see.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And what's that to you, blind Bitch? will you mount the Trojan Horse, and drive the Pigmies like Geese before you?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Drunk, upon my Honour; stark Drunk.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis for my Master's Honour, Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I am told too, you keep a Whore in Town.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis for my Master's Credit— Kiss me Baud— I will salute thy precious Person; I will salute thy nether Lip.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The Knave is loving in his Drink. ----- Nay, fie; pish, fie; I do protest I will cry out a Rape.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do'st thou hear, Doxie? Old Touchstone is a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Mercy on me! an Alderman a Cuckold ----- past Grace, that's certain. I must proceed to Execution ----- There's Ense rescidendum for you, Sirrah; there's your Indentures; all your Apparel that I know
of is upon your Back; and so my Heart and Doors henceforth are shut upon thee.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Am I free then? Old Satan, I will tell thee

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What now, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: When this eternal substance of my Soul—

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I was a Courtier in the Spanish Court, and Don Andrea was my Name.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Good Master, Don Andrea, will you march?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I will piss upon thy Threshold, and throw rotten Eggs against thy Sign-Post— ha! dost thou shake thy goary Locks at me?— avaunt, I say.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Help! Murder, murder.

sp.stage: Security and his Wife Playing at Putt, Syndefie by them.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: There's up, Wynny, there's up; Come give me my Winnings.

Look you there now; is not this better than to throw away Guinneys at heathenish Bassett, and Comett? there is no Game, for Invention, like Putt and One and Thirty: My Sow has Pigg'd too, is a notable piece of Skill.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Now, Sirrah, where have you been loitering all this while? let me see, thou hast been a whole half hour, five minutes, and three crochets compleatly.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Master Quick-silver, Sir, is drown'd at present in the Bride-Bowl.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And hast thou been at Mr. Bramble's Chamber in the Temple?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ' has dispatcht his Client, and only stays for a Fee on the other side too, before he waits upon you.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Fees on both sides may make a reasonable Livelihood ----- Come nearer, Sirrah; and breathe upon me— Wine, Wine upon my Conscience; would you think it, Mrs. Syn? this Rogue has tasted Wine; swallow'd it.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: O, most unconscionable Hound!

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: A single Pint, Sir, between a Friend and I.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And you Treated? Sixpence at a sitting, Rogue?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Once in Seven years, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p:
Once in Seven years, Varlet? dost thou know what that amounts to? Thou art a lusty young Knave, and scaping Tyburn, may'st live this Seventy years yet. I will demonstrate to thee Sixpence once in every Seven
years, Use upon Use, will in that time arise to Twenty four Pound Twelve Shillings. What a Fortune art thou fal'n from— Thou hast seen this Mr. Bramble, Wynny, an unconscionable old Rogue, that keeps his Wife lockt up.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Why then do you use me so?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I do it out of Love, my Bunting; that Knave does it out of Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: As if you were not Jealous.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Not Jealous in the least; I am only afraid thou should'st make me a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Come, Cue; you promis'd I shou'd go abroad the next fair Day, to the Musick-House in the Fields.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: It is not worth thy Pains, my Goldfinch; Look you, I can make you ten times better Musick.
sp.stage: The Froe She wan an Excise, &c.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Ay, but there is a pretty Play in Moor-Fields.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Why, I will act thee a better Play my self. What wilt thou have? The Knight of the Burning Pestle? or, The doleful Comedy of Piramus and Thisbe? That's my Master-Piece; when Piramus comes to be dead, I can act a dead man rarely, The rageing Rocks, and shivering Shocks, shall break the Locks of Prison Gates; And Phoebus Carr, shall shine from Far, to make and marr the foolish Fates.— Was not that lofty, now? Then there's the Lion, Wall and Moonshine, three Heroick Parts; I Play'd 'em all at School. I roar'd out the Lion so terribly, that the Company call'd out to me to roar again.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: I, Cue; but there is the Italian Piece, at Charing-Cross.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You mean Punch, my intimate Friend and Acquaintance? I knew Old Punch his Grandfather ----- you shall see.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Clogg, get me a Squib to compleat the Sport.
sp.stage: [Syndesie lays the Squib under his Chair, and blows him up. Quick-silver enters upon them.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, how now Dad? what merry Pranks are these?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, Francis; a little conjugal Conceit for my Wife's Diversion ---- ah Lard, that my Gravity should be so apprehended ----- Come up, Wynny, ---- come to thy Chamber.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Now, my dear Syn, I am free as Elemental Air; the Indented Sheep-skin's Burnt, in which I was wrapt; like Sampson, I have broke Philistian Bonds, and in thy Arms, my lovely Dalilah ----- Come, let my Trunks shoot forth their Silks conceal'd, and deck me like a Bridegroom.
sp.stage: [She brings forth his Periwigg, Crevat, Sword, &c. and puts them on him.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: But alas, Frank, how will this Bravery be maintain'd now? your Place maintain'd it before.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why? and I maintain'd my Place.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: There is no standing without Leggs, nor flying without Wings, Frank; there's none but must have Trades to live withal.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Away with your mouldy Proverbs, Trades to live withal? No, I say, still let him that has Wit, live by his Wit; and he that has none, let him be a Tradesman.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Witty, Master Francis! Indeed 'tis pity any Trade should dull that quick Brain of yours— Well, do but bring Knight Petronell into my Parchment Toyls, and you shall never need to drudge in any Trade— o' my Credit, you shall not; I do hunger and thirst to do thee good— Do'st thou know his Wife's Land? do'st thou?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Even to a foot, Sir; I have been often there. A very fine Seat, good Land, all intire within it self.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Well wooded, Frank? well wooded?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Seven hundred Pounds worth ready to Fell, and a fine sweet House that stands just in the midst of it, like a point in the middle of a Circle.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Excellent Master Francis! how I long to do the good! I even die, that thou may'st inherit my Possessions— for, on my Religion, Master Francis, I meddle in this affair to do the Knight a Pleasure; and so 'pray tell him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Get him the Money ready then, Dad; for inter nos, all that he was able of himself to raise, is laid out on a Ship now bound for Virginia; the manner of which Voyage is so closely laid, that neither his Lady-Bride, nor any of her Friends know of it. Therefore as soon as her Hand is gotten to the Sale of the Inheritance, and you have furnish'd him with the Money, he will instantly hoist Sail and away.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And a frank gale go with him, Master Frank ---- alas, we have too few such Knights Adventurers; let his Wife Seal to Day, he shall have the Money to Day.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This very Morning she intends for the Countrey to work, to which Action, with more Engines, I purpose presently to prefer my sweet Syn here to her, for her Gentlewoman; whom you, for better Credit, shall present as your Kinswoman, newly come up to learn Fashions.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: On my Religion, a most pithy Project; as good she spoil the Lady, as the Lady spoil her ----- Syn, you are bound to Master Francis.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Look you, here is the Knight come already.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Petronell with a Writing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll leave this fulsome Town immediately, here's no Diversion stirring; Wit is at low Ebb, and Wickedness at a stand; I will away immediately.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You would do well to take some Guinneys in your Pocket, Knight, or your Eastward Castle will smoak but miserably.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My Castle? why, thou know'st, Frank, that all my Castles are in the Air.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why? whither is your Lady going then?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'faith to seek her Fortune; I think I told her I had a Castle Eastward, and Eastward she will go; her Coach, and the Coach of the Sun must meet full Butt.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But how will you pacifie her, Knight, when her Enchanted House becomes invisible.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I warrant you, 'tis but telling her she mistook my Directions, and that I will shortly down with her my self; in the mean time, 'tis but clapping a new Gown upon her Crupper—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well said, Old Dad;— a mongst Friends, Knight, where have you made your choice? the King's-Bench, or which of the two Compters? for my part, I like neither of them.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: There is no jesting, Frank, with my Necessity. Thou know'st, that if I raise not present Money for my Voyage, all's lost with me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, that's the very Point, Sir; get but your Lady to set her Hand to the Sale of her Inheritance, and my old Blood-hound here, shall smell out ready Money instantly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: There spoke my Angel. I have brought her to it, and feigning my self most extreamly amorous, have urg'd Excuses for my stay behind. Child was never so impatient to ride a Cock-horse, than she is to hansel her new Coach with a Journey.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: She would long for every thing, when she was a Maid. I'll lay my life she will have four Children every year; what Charge and Humour must you endure that while? and how will she hold you to your Tackle, till she is with Child?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay, there is no Turn-spit Dog bound to his Wheel more servilely, than you will be to hers; for as the Dog never climbs to the top of his Wheel, but when the Wheel comes under him; so— you understand me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well said, Old Dad, again; nay, hark you, Sir; what Nurses, what Midwives, what Fools, what Physicians, what Cunning-Women and Cronies, to tell her Tales, talk Bawdy to her, make her Laugh, let her Blood—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee no more: What a Death is my Life bound face to face unto? the best on't is, that a large time-fitted Conscience is bound to Nothing. This Indian Voyage will set all to Rights— but see she comes to seek me out, and take her leave of me.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And Mr. Bramble in the very Nick too; get her to Seal immediately; for I do hunger and thirst to do you good, Sir.

sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Touchstone, Girtred, Bramble, Syndefie: Girtred in a Chair, with Page and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Further, ye dull English Blockheads, further. If I were but Lady Mayoress, you must have brought me past the Portico— Your Servant, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Your Ladiships most humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: What a Bloom am I in all over? give me my Fan; I protest I am in general Damp.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Here is your Ladiships Handkerchief, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Thank you, Mrs. Touchstone— Well, my dear Knight, I'll take notice of you in Company now, because it is within our Month; but hereafter, as I am a Lady, you must not expect it; it is not Alamode for Persons of our Quality.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We will be careful to neglect each other, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I have a humble suit to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: You are welcom— but hold, you must not put on your Hat yet; Master Francis Quick-silver,— as I am a Lady, I did not know him: he makes me blush so, that my Eyes stand with Water; would I were unmarry'd again.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I hope your Ladiship has no reason to repent—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: No; but you know the first sight of a Bride puts strange Thoughts— what were you saying, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That your Ladiship would please to accept my Kinswoman here, to your Service; she's newly come up out of the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Is she a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: She is, Madam; and one that her Father has a mind to bestow in some honorable Lady's Service too—

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: To learn Breeding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And surely you have a discreet Choice in preferring her to her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: We suppos'd that, Mrs. Touchstone: These City Gentlewomen are so forward --- And can you do any Work that belongs to a Lady's Chamber?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: What I cannot do, I shall be glad to learn, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And d'ye hear— Old Gentleman, you may put on your Hat now, I do not look on you— I must have you of my Faction, not of my Knight's, to draw all the Servants to my Bow, to tell me Tales, put me Riddles, read Aristotle while I am dressing, to laugh extreamly at the Countrey Gentlewomen when they have made me Visits, to take no Care what is spent in the House, for it is all mine; and in any Case to be still a Maid whatever you do, and whatever any Man can do to you.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I am your Creature, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Very well, you shall ride down in my Coach with me immediately— is it not come yet? upon my Quality, I think I am with Child already, I long so for my Coach. Can I be with Child so soon, Mrs. Touchstone?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: But will your Ladiship be gone before I can possibly wait on you?

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Let me, dear Knight: I d' so long to dress up thy Castle before thou com'st.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: But must this little man, Madam, run all the Way a foot?

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: I warrant him; He gives no other Milk, as yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis pity: Good Madam, buy him a Hobby-horse; let the poor Knave have something.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: You are impertinent, Mrs. Touchstone.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Your Coach is come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Is my Coach come? why, that's well said: methinks I am up to the Knees in Preferment: farewel, Knight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Will not your Ladiship be pleas'd first to Sign a slight Paper here?

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Deed of Sale of your Countrey Seat: Mine is more large, and stands more pleasantly, only the Arras being something faded, must now be chang'd to Wainscot; and now for a Lady's Bed-Chamber Alcoves are all the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: I will have it all laid out upon my Castle; give me the Pen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: What is your Ladiship a doing?

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Interrogating again, Mrs. Touchstone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: I will wait on your Ladiship to your Coach: I shall never sleep till I hear your Ladiship is safe in your Castle, Madam, and that you live safe there too.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Fear it not, Mrs. Touchstone: There were Gyants in it formerly, but my Knight has kill'd 'em all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And therefore he was Knighted, I presume.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Upon my Honour the Day wears apace; come Chairmen carry me to my Coach— Adieu, Knight— upon my Quality you shall not stir one step.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Heav'n bless your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Thankyou, good People, thank you.
sp.stage: [She is carry'd round the Stage and so off bowing to the Company from each side of her Chair.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Was there ever such an Adventure?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why this, I hope, is not the first false Journey that a Lady has taken in her Coach.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: But when her Knight is upon a real Voyage.—

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Sir Petronell, where are you? Captain Seagult stays for you on Board; it will be Flood within this two hours.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We shall be time enough to reach Black-wall, where our Ship lies, against Tide.

Master Security, you see the urgency of my Affair; meet me an hour hence at the Swan Tavern by Billingsgate, with your Money; and these shall there be made over to you: and, Mr. Bramble, we must desire your Presence at the Delivery.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: You have no further Service for me, Gossip?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nothing at present, Gossip.
Did you observe that peaching Petti-fogger, Gentlemen? a Jealous old Hunks, that locks up his Wife.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Cue, Where is my Cue, there?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Here Bunting.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Won't you come Putt with me above Stairs, Cue?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I am busy, Bunting.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: But oneword, Cue.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I will along with you immediately.
sp.stage: [Exit. [As he is going up, She calls to Sir Petr. throws him down a Letter, and retires.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: There is the Remora to my Voyage, Frank,— how shall I sail and leave my Heart behind?— See here. [Reads.
I have over-heard your Voyage, and would share your Adventure; deliver me from this Enchanted Castle, as you are a true Knight Errant.
Now Frank, my subtle Mercury, instruct me;
This were of a Master-piece of rare Invention,
Could I but get this Helen once aboard,
Not Paris past the Seas with half such Pride.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I have a suddain lucky thought.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It is impossible, our time's so short; The Husband's watch is so shy upon her while he is within, and when he goes forth, he comes directly to us. Rust choak him, he's here again.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Leave me to work him.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, shall we dispatch? to the Tavern I know our noble Knight will pay his Way: we'll take up the Money as we go; I am impatient till I do him good.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Knight will Treat most freely. But first, Dad, we have a weighty Secret to impart to you in which we must have your wise Assistance. This Gentleman, my Friend, has enjoy'd a Gentlewoman whom you well know—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How's that? a Gentlewoman whom I well know?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Woman is your learned Councel's Wife, Mr. Bramble, that was here e'en now.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Why? he deserves it, Frank; for keeping her lockt up. I could contribute to my learn'd Councel's Cuckoldom; but you say, the Gentleman has enjoy'd her already; wherein then can I assist him further?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: He wants to take the dear farewel; and therefore, Dad, if you will but take pains to bring out Mr. Councel, your Gossip, to the Tavern where we are to meet—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay, I would have him present at the delivery of the Deed.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I will watch his coming out, and bring his Wife disguis'd into our Company; think but what Sport 'twill be to gull his Circumspection.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: On my Religion, a most pithy Project! who would not strain a point of Friendship for such a neat Device? ha! ha! ha! and the sport will be to hear me Bob and Cut upon him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Was there ever such an old Villain? it works rarely.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: To over-reach that Head that over-reaches all Heads, will be a Plot rampant; well, I hope this Harvest to pitch Carts with Lawyers, their Heads shall be so fork'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: But how shall we disguise her on the suddain?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A Sailor's Gown and Cap, and Player's Beard.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: But how shall she make bare her head, when thou present'st her to our Company? I think it best not to have her appear.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Not for the World, I must have her coram; the very Soul o'th' mirth is lost else— I have hit it; you shall see, Gentlemen, what an old Brain can do; I'll fetch you a Disguise.
Look, Gentlemen, here is my Wife's best Gown, which you may put upon the Lawyer's Wife; and for her Face it shall be Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Most excellent.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And for doing this, I have two Politick Reasons. One is, That Mr. Bramble may thereby have some suspicion that it is my Wife; and thereupon gird me with his Lawyer's Wit. The other Reason is, That I shall be sure of my own Wife's staying at home the while; for she will never go abroad undress'd; d'ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: With Admiration.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Is it not rare? was I not born to furnish Gentlemen? Come hither, Clogg.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Take this Key, and let your Mistress down into this Room for Air, till I come home again.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Knight, he'll leave her freedom of the House till he returns; so that as soon as he goes out to the Lawyers, I will slip in hither again with these Cloths of his Wife's, dress her up in them, and bring her Masqu'd to the Tavern, while he shall suppose her the Lawyer's.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I will but send to Mr. Cash to have our Money ready against I come from my Gossips.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You see, Knight, we have shamm'd my Dad here, with a Pretence on his Gossip's Wife; what will you say if I make Earnest of it, and deliver that Lady from her enchanted Castle too?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And so to go aboard with us? that were a Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: We have been private Acquaintance too: I have sent a pretended Attorney with a Sham Sub-Poena for her to be Witness in a Cause this Afternoon, at the same time that Mr. Councel is to be with us at the Swan with your Deed; and rather than have her forfeit for Non-Appearance he will let her come abroad; by which means she will have Opportunity of meeting me by the Water-side.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Most admirable! what a History shall we leave behind us, Frank?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, shall we be stirring?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: How impatient he is, as 'twere the Devil going to fetch the Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And Devil He shall be, if Horns can make him.

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Come, Drawer, Pierce your neatest Hogsheads, and let us have Entertainment fit for our noble Colonel: He'll be here instantly.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You shall have all things to your wish, Sir: wil't please ye to have more Wine?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Without measure, Slave; whether we drink it or no, spill it and draw more.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Well spoken, noble Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Fill all your Pots and Bottles; rank 'em like Souldiers, and though we do not presently employ 'em, we'll keep 'em in Pay till we do.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You shall have all you will Command, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Come Boys, this Indian Cantlet longs till we have it's Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: But is there such Treasure there, as we are told?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Vast endless Mines: for so much red Copper as I carry thither, I will have thrice the weight in Gold. They hinge their Doors with it, and barr their Windows.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: But do you meet no Clipticks nor Tropiques by the way? I pray what sort of things are they?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Why, monstrous Creatures; not much unlike your Elephant; but there is your Calenture is more inclining to a Dragon.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: And is it a pleasant Countrey Captain?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: As ever the Sun shin'd on; you have Autumn, Winter, Spring. Summer there, all without any change of Seasons, and that you'd wonder at.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: And what Government, good Captain?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: You shall live free there without Sergeants, Lawyers, or Intelligencers; you may be an Alderman, without being a Scavinger; attain any Office, without ' Prenticeship; you may come to Preferment, without being a Pimp; to Riches and Fortune enough and have never the more Villany nor the less Wit. In a word, you will have no more Law than Conscience, and not too much of either.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: And how far thither, Captain?

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: Some six Weeks Sail with an Indifferent Wind, and if I get to the Coast of Africa, I'll Sail with any Wind; or if we make the Cape Finister, we have a fore-right Wind till we come thither— But see our noble Colonel!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well met, good Captain Seagull, and my noble Gentlemen; now our sweet hour of freedom is at hand: Come Drawer, fill us our Bumpers, to raise us for the mirth that will be occasion'd presently— Here will be a pretty Wench, Gentlemen, that will bear us Company all our Voyage.

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: To her health, noble Colonel, with Cap and Knee.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thank you, good Captain, she's one whom I love dearly; but must not have her known till we are aboard; and so, Gentlemen, here's to her Health.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Let it come, worthy Colonel, we do both thirst and hunger for it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Right, Sirs, you hit the very Phrase of him that is my Pimp and Cuckold too; though both unwittingly. About with it.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: See there, Gossip Bramble, their Voyage needs must prosper; they are on their Knees for success to it— Save my brave Colonel, and his tall Captains: see, Sir, my learn'd Gossip Councel Bramble, is come to take his leave of you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Health to my learn'd Councel.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You must bend too Gossip.

sp.speaker: C. Sea.
sp.p: By your leave, Sir, he must not Pledge his own Health.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: No, Master Captain;
Then here is one sitly come to do him that Honour.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Here is the Gentlewoman your Cousin, Sir, whom with much entreaty, I have brought to take her leave of you in a Tavern; and for that Reason the Company must excuse her that she puts not off her Masque.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pardon me, dear Cousin, my hurry and hast of business at my going, forc'd me to give you this Trouble.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Thanks to your good Contrivance, my dear Cousin.
sp.stage: [Puts off her Mask to him aside, and puts it on again.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Come hither, Wax,— Here, take the Key of your Mistresses Chamber, 'tis high time for her to attend the Court; I must not have her forfeit: Be sure you stir not from her: And as soon as she has done witnessing, see her Home again; Lock her up in her Chamber again, and bring me the Key to my Gossip Security's.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How's that, Mr. Francis? have you honour'd the Company with the Presence of a fair Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray Sir, take you no notice of her; for I can assure you, she will not be known to you.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Good; but my learn'd Gossip Councel Bramble here, I hope may know her? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No more than you at present, his Learning must Pardon her.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Heav'n Pardon her, and for my part, I do.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And so, Mr. Francis, Here's to all this good Company that goes Eastward, presently towards Cuckold'-Haven— not forgetting my learn'd Gossip Bramble.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Has it gone round, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It has, dear Frank; and terminates in thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then --- here is Eastward, Gentlemen, and so to Cuckold's-Haven.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: What can this mean? that word strikes Terror through me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee, Couz, weep no more— Master Security.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: What says my dear Knight?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Our Friend, Mrs. Bramble here, is so dissolv'd in Tears, that she drowns the whole Mirth of our Meeting; I do beseech you speak to her.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: 'Tis shame and pity, Mrs Bramble; what weep in Presence of your Love? What's the Cause, Lady? is it because your Husband is so near?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And your Heart earns that you have a little abus'd him?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Alas, the Offence is too common to be regarded.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: That's true.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You are to blame to heed a jealous Dotard.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: To steal to a young Lover.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Once more to Cuckolds'-Haven, Gentlemen,— you'll Pledge me, Gossip? let's have a frisk of footing too: Come, have you pledg'd Cuckold's-Haven, Gossip?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Strike up there.
sp.stage: [Here they all Dance, and compass Wynifred in.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Sir Petronell, your Cousin here is still in Tears; pray take her aside a little and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: With your fair leave, Mr. Security.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Most heartily.
sp.stage: [He Locks in Sir Petr. and his Wife together.
sp.p: Come Sirs, anothér Round; He that refuses to be drunk to Night, let him be never Sober.
sp.stage: [While the rest Drink, he goes hearkning to the Door.
sp.p: About with it, 'tis to Sir Petronell, and all his Captains— you want it, Gossip. This Cuckold's-Haven runs so in my mind.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: But heark you, Gossip, is not that Gentlewoman your Wife, that's gone in with the Knight?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Why should you think so, Gossip?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Because the shape and dress are very like.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Cucullus non facit Monachum, my Learned Councel; All are not Cuckolds that seem so, nor do all seem so that are so— Oh, I break my Ribs!
So, now Colonel and Captains, a good Voyage to you, Adieu: I know you do not go my Way to Night, Gossip— This Cuckold's-Haven runs so in my Head.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: There is some Mystery in this; I must needs after him to be satisfy'd. Adieu, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Sir Petronell, here is one of your Watermen come to tell you it is Flood, and that it will be dangerous going against Tide; for the Skies are over-cast, and there was a Porpiece seen just now below the Bridge.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No matter, we can reach Black-Wall against Tide, and in spight of Tempests. Come, one Round more, Gentlemen, while I discharge the House.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: About with it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Enough: Now Charge a Boat. Come, my fair Helen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Boat, a Boat, a Boat.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Come, Clogg, help on with my Gown and Cap— so, very well;

What a notable Device was this? well, what with the Conceit of it, and my Wine together, methinks I am somewhat exhilarated, and feel as it were an Inclination to Conjugal Performance: My Bunting will be surpriz'd extreamly— Do'st hear, Lark, Linnet, Goldfinch— This is ever her way, always at her Devotion in my Absence; I must disturb her.
No-body here?— Clogg, Rogue, Vermin.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: What is your Worship's pleasure?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Where is your Mistress, Varlet?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Abroad Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Abroad without my leave? then I am certainly a Cuckold. What, go abroad in her Night Dress?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: In her Best Cloths, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How's that? How came she by 'em?

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: Your Friend, Sir, Master Quick-silver brought 'em in hither, stay'd till she put 'em on, and then took Coach with her, I heard 'em bid the Coachman drive to the Tavern at the Bridge foot.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Monstrum horrendum: my Gossip was in the Right: what a Trap have I laid for my Self? why, then she is not only Whor'd; but for ought I know, spirited away to the Indies.

sp.speaker: Clogg.
sp.p: She cry'd, indeed, farewel for ever, Cage.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I'll Plow up Rocks steep as the Alps in Dust,
And lave the Tyrrhene Waters into Clouds,
But I will reach them.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: The Matter Gossip? what transports you so?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Undone for ever, Gossip; 'twas my Wife; on my Religion I thought she was yours. Call me Ten Coaches, and as many Constables, I will to this wicked place again, and seize the Traytors.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: They are all upon the Thames e're now, and if that Lady was your Wife, she's in the Boat with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I'll take Boat after 'em, and fire their Ship.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Take Boat in this tempestuous Night? Heark, how it Rains and Thunders.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I care not for the Weather, I will Row after to Black-Wall.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: And pray touch in at Cuekold's-Haven, Gossip.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Furies and Fate— but hold, I must see first if she ha' taken any of my rich Pawns along with her.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Well for my Gossip, to intend my Wife, and get himself Cornuted! ha, ha, ha.— How now, Wax?

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: Oh! where is my Master Bramble? my poor Master, Bramble?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: What now, Sirrah? hast thou neither Eyes nor Ears?

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: Sir, I have no Senses left! Oh, Sir, your Wife, my Mistress!

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, did not I give you the Key to lock her up at Home, as soon as she had witness'd?

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: O, Sir, there was no witnessing; her Sub-Poena was all Sham, instead of going to Westminster, she drove to Pater-noster-Row, where she took up Silks in your Name by whole Pieces, and so on to the Goldsmiths in Cheap-siae, and Goldsmiths in Lumbard-street, where she took up Rings and Jewels, all in your Name still; from thence she went to the Swan at Bridge-foot, where Mr. Quick-silver met her, took her to the Water, and instead of coming back Westward by Coach, she's gone Eastward by Boat; Oh! ho! ho!

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Dar'st thou live to tell me this, Rogue? thy Name is Wax, Thou should'st have stuck to her.

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: I did, Sir, till they push'd me off with their Oars, and sows'd me in the Mudd.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I'll Plow up Rocks steep as the Alps in Dust,
And lave the Tyrrhene Waters into Clouds;
But I will reach'em.
O, Whore unconscionable! what? Silks, Rings, and Jewels, to such a Quantity, along with her.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Even so, Gossip, she has taken all with her.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Mock me not, Gossip, I mean my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: My Wife, that's run away by Water.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Mine's run away by Water too.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Your's gone too!

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Call me Ten Boats, I'll after'em, and fire their Ship.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: What in this tempstuous Night? heark, how it Rains and Thunders.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I do defie all weathers; I'll after to Black-Wall.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: And pray call in at Cuckold's-Haven, Gossip.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Furies and Fate!— a Boat! a Boat! a Boat!

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: A Boat! a Boat! a Boat!

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

lg.l: HOw great are the Blessings of Government made,
By the excellent Rule of our Prince?
Who, while Trouble and Cares do his Pleasures invade,
To his People all Joy does dispense:
And while He for us is still carking and thinking,
We have nothing to Mind, but our Shops and our Trade,
And then to divert us with Drinking.
From him we derive all our Pleasure and Wealth:
Then fill me a Glass, nay, fill it up higher,
My Soul is a thirst for His Majesty's Health,
And an Ocean of Drink can't quench my Desire:
Since all we Enjoy, to his Bounty we Owe,
'Tis fit all our Bumpers like that shou'd O'erflow.

sp.stage: Cuckold's Point. Enter a Butcher's Man with a Pair of Oxe Horns.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: HAil, thou fair Haven of Marry'd Men; for my part, I presume not to arrive here, but only in Right of my Master, who sent me thus early to put up these necessary Ensigns of his Homage.

Stand fast, good Timber, or I shall be blown into the Thames: I think the Devils be abroad in a Storm to rob me of my Horns. The Thames roars like any Ocean-Sea. Mercy on all honest Passengers. So, I think I have made it look the right way, it fronts the City directly. How now, Tom?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No vent'ring by Water yet: Here has been most bloody work to Night.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: As how, prithee?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, several People Drown'd.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: What did none 'scape?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not one of them that were Drown'd, for all that I can yet hear: just by the Fisher's Hutt below yonder, there was a Boat over-turn'd, three Men Passengers and a Gentlewoman. You may see 'em all shifted into the Old Fisherman's Wardrobe; but the Woman wisely went to Bed.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: Heark! what Cry is that?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A poor old Man in Gown and Night-cap, just crawl'd out of the River.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Misfortune upon Misfortune, I have a hundred Drums in my Head; and half the Thames in my Belly— Let me see, where am I cast ashoar, that I may go home a righter way by Land? where is there any Sea-Mark, that I am acquainted withal?

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: Look up, Father, are you acquainted with this Ensign?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: What am I Landed at Cuckold's Point? I cannot bear it: I will run back and drown my self.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Let it be in some warmer Liquor, Father: Come, we'll lead you to the next House.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I will enter into no House, and look no Mortal in the Face; they are all Cuckold-makers.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.p: How his Wits are benum'd with Wet and Cold, throw a Hide over him, Tom, and help lead him along.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Petronell, Quick-silver, and Sea-gull, in Fisherman's Cloths and Nets wrapt about them.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A very fair Voyage we have made on't, my Masters; if our Throats had not been too full of Claret to take in one drop of Water, we had lodg'd with the Flounders till our Calls had burst: well, 'tis but imagining we are arriv'd at some Outlandish Place, and these the Habits of the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Capt. Sea.
sp.p: I tell ye, Sirs, for all this we are gotten to the Coast of Normandy, I know it by the Elevation of the Pole, and the Altitude of the Climate; this is nothing with us Sailors: I have been Drown'd forty times in my Life, before now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: One dry Hanging had done us better Service, Captain: How much Weight of Gold can you get for red Copper in this Countrey, Captain?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, we have just as much Copper as Gold left, Frank; the unmerciful Thames has swallow'd All. Our Boat turn'd oft'ner than a Juggler's bag, and rowl'd like any Porpice. Now if my Lady Wife has had as good a Land Passage on't, as we have had by Water.

sp.speaker: 1 Bay.
sp.p: These must be the Persons; Seize 'em: You have been sows'd in the Thames, Gentlemen, and a particular Friend of yours has sent us to take you out of the Cold Air.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Pox of your Charity; what damn'd luck had we that could not Drown.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: At whose Arrest, Scoundrels?

sp.speaker: 2 Bay.
sp.p: Only Alderman Touchstone desires to take his leave of you before you Sail to the Indies; will you march along, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This must be the Coast of Normandy, Captain; you know it by the Elevation of the Pole.
sp.stage: Enter more Officers, with Security in the Oxe Hide.

sp.speaker: 1 Bay.
sp.p: See, yonder comes our Mates with old Mammon.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, there's some Comfort yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Bay.
sp.p: Come, Brothers, let us home with the whole Covey together.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Rogues, Turks, Tartars, I will not drive one step further. This is Cuckold's-Haven, and I will die on my own Territories.

sp.speaker: 1 Bay.
sp.p: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Thinks my Knight Adventurer that we ken no Point of our Compass? Have we never heard of the Speranza, the Cavillaria, nor the Calinoria? well, my Errant Flash, and Runnegate Quick-silver, you may hurl a dozen Caps to your bon Voyage; but if you reach any Point but Cuckolds, with this Tide, I'il give you leave to make a Gravesend-Toast of me. I have sent your Pinnace a Remora, and that from this Sconce of mine, without Powder or Shot— Work upon that now.
