Here's Land Intelligence too, from my Lady Daughter, and her Ladiship's Luck is as good as the Rest; She'll come to her Castle, and they to the Indies, much about a time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: What, no News yet from her Ladiship? but we must allow Persons of Quality their own time for things.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, here is a small Pacquet from her Ladiship; she has been seeking her Castle in the Air; in what Region I know not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: I hope your Mechanick Worship will have the Manners to stay her Ladiship's leisure; no matter for her Castle, what Account does her Ladiship send of that fair Tenement of her Body?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Why, the fair Tenement of her Body, and her Maids Body were benighted on the Common with their Coach; rob'd, stript and fairly thrown into a Ditch, like two Snails In a Shell, with the Coachman a top on'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: O, Profane Accident, her Ladiship tumbled into a Ditch!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: From whence she is return'd to Town by Waggon, and at present sojourning in a blind Tap-house in Pudding-Lane.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And is this all your concern for the Matter? how if her Ladiship shou'd Miscarry upon it?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: It were not the first time, sure; she has the Blessing to take after her Mother; Thou hast been my Cross these Thirty years, and now I will keep thee to fright away Spirits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: O, Insensible Monster! give me the Directions, I will, fly upon the Wings of Motherly Affection, and wait upon her Ladiship incontinently.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I wonder I hear nothing from my Son Golding yet; he was sent for betimes this Morning to the Guild-hall, and I am astonish'd at the Matter: If I had not laid up some comfort in him, I should e'en grow desperate— He comes in my Thoughts— How now, Son? what News at the Court of Aldermen?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, an Accident somewhat strange, else it has nothing worth reporting.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: It is not borrowing of Money, then?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No, Sir: It has pleas'd the Commoners of the City to make me One of our Ward, to Elect me one of their Common-Council-men.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And the Alderman of our Ward to appoint me his Deputy; in which Office I had an Oath ministred unto me accordingly.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Let me Kiss thy new Worship, my dear Son!— what a Fortune was it, or rather Judgment, for me to see that merit in him, which the whole City conspires to Second? taken into the Livery of his Company the first Week of his Freedom! chosen Common-Council-man, and made an Alderman's Deputy all in a Day! the Wonder of our Times! Well, I will Honour Mr. Alderman for this, and think the better of the Common-Councils Wisdom while I live, for thus meeting, or rather coming after me in the Opinion of his Desert: Forward, my sufficient Son; and as this was the first, so think it the least step of thy Promotion.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir, as I was not ambitious of this; so I seek no higher.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Excellently spoken again! this Modest Answer of thine blushes, as if it said, Thou shalt wear Scarlet shortly; I must tell thee, I hope to see thee the other Monument of our City, reckon'd among our Worthies, and remembred on the same Day with Gresham and my Lady Ramsey: when Whittington and his Puss shall be forgotten, and thy own Deeds play'd in thy own Time, by the best Company of Moor-Fields.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You are too Prodigal of your Praise, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well, I have a little News for thee too: Our lewd Crew are all in the Officers Clutches e're now; and thou shalt exercise Authority by way of justice on 'em.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your Pleasure, Sir, shall guide me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: See, the Officers are at the Door without; How miraculously it falls out that thou should'st have the Place of a Justicer upon 'em: I am glad of the Injury they have done me, that thou may'st punish it: Disgrace 'em all thou can'st, be severe upon them, like a new Officer of the first Quarter.

sp.stage: Enter Sir Petronell, Quick-silver, Seagull, brought.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: How implacably this Devil of ill Fortune pursues us?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Take your Chair, Mr. Justicer; I say, appear terrible to 'em; let 'em know the Melancholy of a Magistrate, and taste the Fury of a Citizen in Office.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir, I can do nothing with them, unless your Worship charge them with somewhat.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Fear not that, I will charge 'em and re-charge 'em rather than Authority shall want Matter to work upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will your Worship please to Sit?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: By no means, Son, it is your Office.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Must Golding Sit upon us?

sp.speaker: Fang.
sp.p: Plain Golding, to Mr. Deputy's Worship?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What Persons have ye there, Mr. Officer?

sp.speaker: Fang.
sp.p: The same, an' please your Worship, that were specify'd in our Warrant. This, Sir, is the Counterfeit Knight; This, his lewd Companion.—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What? a Knight and his Companion thus accoutred? where are their Hats and Feathers, their Cloaks and Perriwiggs?

sp.speaker: Fang.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, they had cast their Feathers before we seiz'd 'em. Here's all the furniture we found amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Their Names, I say?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O this is most excellent: he should not take knowledge of 'em in his Place, indeed.

sp.speaker: Fang.
sp.p: Why, this, Sir, is Sir Petronell Flash.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Fang.
sp.p: And this, Master Quick-silver.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Is it possible? I thought they had been gone to Virginia e're now with this Noble Captain. You have made a quick return it seems, and doubtless a good Voyage— nay, Pray Sirs, be cover'd; how did your Bisket hold out, I beseech you?— Sure I have seen this Outlandish Gentleman before. Good Master Quick-silver, how one degree to the Southward has alter'd you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you know these Persons, Mr. Alderman?— forbear your offers a little, you shall be heard anon.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Yes, Mr. Deputy, I had a small Venture aboard with them: Officers, you may let 'em stand; I'll pass my word they will not run away: A Brace of honest Gentlemen. One of 'em was my 'Prentice, that kept his Whore and Hunting-Nagg; would Play you his Hundred Guinneys off at Basset most familiarly; and all on my Purse. In fine, there was no remedy but we must part; for I shall be very concise, Mr. Deputy. Since which time (for, as I said, I intend to be very concise with your Worship) since when, I say, he has gather'd up some small Parcels of mine amongst my Customers, to the value of seven Hundred
Pound more towards furnishing this Indian Voyage, wherein this Knight was Chief, Sir Flash here, one that Marry'd a Daughter of mine, Ladify'd her, turn'd Two thousand Pound of good Land of hers into Cash, sent her a Progress to his invisible Castle, while he prepar'd for Sea, with a certain Usurers Wife, an' please you, Master Deputy. Now to pronounce your honourable Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: If my Worshipful Father have ended.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have an' please you, Master Deputy.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why then under Correction.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hold a little, Son,— Now come over 'em with some fine Gird, as thus,— Knight, you shall be encountred; that is to say, had to the Compter; and Quick-silver, I will put you into a Crucible, or so,— ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Then as the honourable Laws direct in these Cases.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hold yet a little, Mr. Deputy, that your Worship may not be over-burden'd, I will officiate a little.

Sir Petronell Flash, I am sorry to see such flashes as these come from you: for my own part d'ye see (because I will be concise with you) I cou'd wish I cou'd say, I cou'd say, I cou'd wish, that I cou'd say, I cou'd not see 'em; but such is the misery of Magistrates, and Men in Place, that we must not wink at Offenders: fiat Justicia, ruat Coelum.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And then your Worship may catch Larks.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Without your Worship's Net, Sir,— that I think was Wormwood, I love Bobbing in a Magistrate extreamly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will your Worship proceed?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Master Francis Quick-silver, would thou had'st turn'd Quacksalver: Thou art a proper young Man; of an honest and clean Face, somewhat near a good one; but thou hast been too proud of it. Thou hast Prodigally consum'd thy Master's Wealth on light Housewifes: And being by him gently admonisht at several times, thou hast return'd thy self haughty, rebellious in thine Answers, thundering out uncivil Comparisons, requiting all his Kindness with Coarse behaviour: I must tell thee, Francis, these are most manifest signs of an obstinate ill Nature— so much for Authority, now by way of Evidence.
sp.stage: [He places Golding again in the Chair.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your Worship has acquitted your self most judiciously.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your Worship do's me too much Honour—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This Mockery is the worst of Tortures.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, impudent Varlet! with what Forehead can'st thou speak, having run such a Course of Riot? does not this Worshipful Person's Temper and Fortune confound Thee? Thy younger Fellow in Service yet, now come to have the Place of a Judge upon thee? Which of all thy Gallants and Gamsters, thy Swearers and Swaggerers, will once condole thee till thou com'st up Holborn in Triumph? for by the Clew of thy Knavery, and thy Chain of Concupiscence, thou hast most certainly brought thy self to the Cart of Calamity.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Worshipful Master.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Offer not to speak, Crocodile; I will not hear a sound from thee: Thou hast learn'd to cry at the Play-house: Will it please you, Master Deputy, to commit 'em all three to safe Custody?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Will you not take Security, Sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Take Security? why, I have him already; Mr. Fang, carry my Usurer and Tarpoulin here, both to the Compter, without Examination: I will lodge my Land-shark and Water-shark in sowce together.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What remains then, but to dispose of these there too, till Mr. Alderman shall be pleas'd to charge them farther: Take 'em away.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This is flat Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No more Respect to Quality?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay, nay; on, on, on: You see here the Issue of Sloth; of Sloth comes Pleasure, of Pleasure comes Riot, of Riot comes Whoring, of Whoring comes spending your Money, whereof comes Theft, whereof comes Judgment, whereof comes Hanging, and so my Quick-silver is fixt.

div.head: SCENE III. A Chamber in an Ale-house.

sp.stage: Girtred and Syndefie in fantastical Old Cloths.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Ah, Syn, did'st thou ever read in the Chronicle, of any Lady and her Gentlewoman driven to that Extremity that we arē, Syn?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Not I truly, Madam; or, if I had, it were but cold Comfort that would come out of Books.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Why? good faith now, I could Dine upon a lamentable old Story; do'st thou know never a one, Syn?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: None but my own, Madam, to be stol'n from my honest Friends by a Prentice in the habit of a Gentleman; upon Promise of Marriage brought to London here, and now likely to be forsaken; for he is in Election to be Hang'd, an' please your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Nay, weep not, good Syn, for my Pett is in as fair Election to be Hang'd as He: Thy miseries are nothing to mine; I was more Promis'd Marriage, Syn; I was Marry'd, and had it, Syn; made a Lady by a Knight, who is now as good as no Knight, Syn; and instead of Land in the Countrey, all his Living lies in the Compter; there is his Castle now, Syn.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: From which he cannot be forc'd out.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Hunger, they say, will break Stone Walls: But he is e'en well enough serv'd, who, as soon as he had got my Hand to the Sale of the Inheritance ran away from my Ladiship, as if I had been his Punk, God bless us. Would the Knight of the Sun, or Palmerin of England have used their Ladies so, Syn? or Sir Lancelot? or Sir Tristram?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I know not, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Then thou know'st nothing, Syn: The Knights now a-days are nothing to the Knights formerly. They rid on Horse-back, ours go on Foot; they went buckled in their Armour, ours muffled in their Cloaks; they travelled Wildernesses, ours dare scarcely walk the Streets; they were still engaging their Honour, ours are ready to Pawn their Cloths: they would spur up at sight of a Monster, ours run away from a Serjeant; they would help poor Ladies, ours make poor Ladies.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: It is most true, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: But let 'em vanish, Syn; yet the Thieves were most unconscionable to take not only our Money, but our Cloths too.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: A timely Consideration, Madam; for our Landlady, prophane Woman, as she is, has sworn by Bread and Salt not to trust us another Meal.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Let it stink in her hands then? she does not know the Honour she enjoys in having a Lady under her Roof— but thy best apparel is gone too, poor Syn.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I grieve for your Ladiship's sake, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Alack! that there are no Fairies now a-days, to do Miracles, and bring Poor Ladies Money: I'll sweep the Hearth at Night; or, why may not we too rise early in the Morning, and find a Jewel in the Streets worth a Hundred Pound, Syn? may not some Court Lady as she comes at Midnight from a Hot-water Shop, look out of her Coach, and lose such a Jewel, Syn?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: These are pretty Dreams, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Well, I protest, Syn, if I had as much Money as an Alderman, I would scatter some of it in the Streets for poor Ladies to find.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: See, Madam, your Mother is coming up Stairs to us.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: What, without sending first up to our Ladiship? upon my Honour 'tis Unsufferable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Where is this unfortunate Emblem of Quality? where is your Ladiship?— O the Father! what a Transmigration is here? I will have my Eyes put out incontinently, that I may not see this absurd Spectacle. What, will not your Ladiship vouchsafe to know me in this Overture of Fortune?

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Not if you presume upon my bad Luck, Mrs. Touchstone; you were best lay the blame upon me now: it was you that shou'd have lok'd to't; I did but my Kind, to desire to be Marry'd, it was my Kind, as a Citizen's Daughter, and to be made a Lady, my Kind still: He was a Knight, and I was fit to be a Lady; 'tis not lack of liking, but lack of living that severs us.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: O good Madam, do not take up your Mother so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Nay, nay, let her alone; let her Ladiship grieve me still with her bitter Taunts: I have not dole enough to see her in this miserable Case, without her Silks, Point, Jewel, Fontanges of seven Stories: without a a little Dog, a Page, or Gentleman-Usher, or any thing that is fit for a Lady.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Except her Tongue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And I not able to relieve her neither, being kept down so as I am by my Husband: Alas! when he was young, I could have come at any think that he had; but now I can come at nothing.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Marry, out on him, for a fousty Mechanick; by this light, I think he is not my legitimate Father. I hope, Mrs Touchstone, you have not debas'd my Quality so much as to ask relief from him— yet when I see— yet when I view this habit in the Glass, it makes the noble Tears gush out—

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Nay, sigh not so, sweet Lady-Bird, dear Madam, Child weep not! I shall die, if you cry and marr your Complexion thus. My Old Touchstone may be a Flint for his obdurateness; but I will try my outmost Power to mollifie him.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Give him seasonable Advice, Mrs. Touchstone; if he humbles himself, in time I may be reconcil'd to him, and accept of a supply from him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Your Ladiship was always good natur'd, I must needs say; he is presently going to the Compter, where your Knight and Mr. Francis are in Durance together: I hear he intends to insult over 'em with his Gold End Son in Law; but by a Letter that I intercepted, I have found an Intrigue of his, to mortifie him with All: Nolens volens he shall Dress you, Coach you, and set you up again, Lady-Child.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Ay, will he set my Knight up too? So my Knight were up, it were no matter though I were down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: But your Ladiship must follow me to the Compter, then your joint Presences will strike an Awe into him: I will hasten before, and send your Ladiship a Coach; your Ladiships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Come Syn, we'll take the Disconsolate Lady of the next Room along with us; I long to hear the Story out of her Water Adventure, and get out of her, who were the Parties concern'd: Her Fisher-womans Straw-Bed, and our Ditch, were Lodgings much alike. Come along, Syn.

sp.stage: Enter Sir Petronell and Quick-silver, dragging in Security by the Horns, Wolf Master of the Prison.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Come, Dad, away with these Penitentials: Old Touchstone has us all in the Wind, and resolves to make Holborn Martyrs of us.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Ah Franck, 'twas ungraciously done of thee, to seduce my Natural Wife, and of you, Sir Knight, to abuse your particular Friend!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That Hunger'd and Thirsted to do me good; your own free Gift, Dad, and you had good Land for it.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: An' my Gossip Bramble, had not known of it, I could have had Mortal Patience.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you had best resolve on some method for your safety. I can assure you Mr. Touchstene will make a Sessions Business of it; and is coming hither in person to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You are under the same Condemnation, Dad, unless you bribe Mr. Wolf here, and make one in our Plot; you must make one at Tyburn, for I shall peach, Dad.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: By no means Franck: I'll do any thing: What Plot?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Master Touchstone has always had great belief in Witchcraft, and is so terrified about it, that he dares never be in the dark: I will counterfeit being Bewitch'd, and you shall lay it to his Charge: He'll do any thing to get quit of us.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Very well; France my Province: I can enact any manner of thing, I was us'd to do it for my Wife's diversion,— it was ungratefully done of you, Sir Knight,— Why, 'tis but rouling my Eyes and foaming at Mouth, (a little Castle-Soap rub'd upon my Lips will do it) and then a Nut-shell with Tow and Touch-wood in it, makes me spit Fire like any Dragon. I Hunger and Thirst to be about it.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Hark, he is at the Gates already; retire, and prepare for the Operation.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But first, Mr. Wolf, give him these Letters and try how far they will work.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You say, Mr. Bramble, the Deed of Sale was of your drawing up, and that you can find Flaws in it.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir: Now shall I be reveng'd on my Gossip for his kind Intentions towards me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Wolf, will you produce your Rats before us?

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Will your Worship be pleas'd to peruse these Letters of Submission from them?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sir, I do look for no Submission; I will bear my self in this Affair like blind Justice: Work upon that now.— Moreover, I do much wonder, Mr. Wolf, that you should travel in this business so contrary to your kind: That you, who are Master of a Prison, should endeavour the Release of your Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: O Sir, I was never so mortify'd with any Mens Discourse or Behaviour in Prison: Yet I have had men of all Nations and Religions.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And which Religion lik'd you best?

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Troth, Mr. Deputy, they that paid their Fees best.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And these are Letters of Humility?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Accept of no Humility, Mr. Alderman, you are a happy Man, and I'll be bound to recover Thousands for you from my Gossip; but then you must be Obstinate.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I warrant you, Mr. Bramble: I am Deaf, and will not hear, have stop'd my Ears with Shooe-makers Wax, drunk Lethe and Mandragora.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Sir, you cannot imagine what a Change is wrought in them; the Knight will be in the Knight's Ward, do what we can: and Quick-silver will be in the Hole, if we wou'd let him. I never saw Prisoners so penitent and devout: They sate up all Night singing the Sinners Complaint, and Edifying the whole Prison. Only Security goes a Note too high sometimes, because he lies in the Two-penny Ward, a great way off, and cannot take his Tune. The Neighbours are not able to rest for 'em, but come to ask what Godly Prisoners we have got there.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Which of 'em is so devout?

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Both Sir, Mr. Quick-silver especially: He has cut his Hair, reads the Young Man's Advice, and has gotten the Sick Man's Salve without Book.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: 'Tis strange he should have no Grace, I am sure he was brought up where it grew.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: He has Converted one Snapp a Bayliff too; a Fellow that could neither Write nor Read: He was call'd the Bandog of the Compter.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Mr. Bramble, I have one Scruple of Conscience; Shall I not lose all if I Prosecute and Hang 'em?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, as to my Gossip Security's Case; though he should be Condemn'd to be Carted for a Bawd, or so; yet I will lay an Execution upon him of two Thousand pound, let him acknowledge a Judgement, he shall do it in half an hour; you shall not fetch him out till you have paid the Execution: This, if I think fit, I can do, Sir, unless you otherwise engage me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You shall have double Fees, Mr. Bramble: Mr. Wolf, set them all Coram.
sp.stage: Enter Petronell, and Quick-silver: They kneel.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Away Syrens. I will immure my self against your Cries.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Who would have thought your Worship were a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What mean the Varlets: I tremble at the Name.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: It will appear so, Sir. Mr. Quick-silver Vomits Nails, and crooked Pins, and in his Fits repeats your Name incessantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Good Mr. Alderman, be not so stiff: I have seen such a Spectacle of Sorrow yonder.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Mr. Bramble, Golding; do I look like a Witch, an Alderman a Witch! I abominated the Black Art from my Cradle.
sp.stage: [Petronell and Quick-silver whisper aside with Mrs. Touchstone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Nay, for my part, I have long suspected him for Necromancy.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Better and better, Master Alderman, here is matter of Scandal for you to proceed against them withal in the Doctors-Commons: This will bear vast Damages.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Let both your Eyes and Ears be Witnesses.
sp.stage: Security brought in, and set upon a Chair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: O the Father! How he stares! This is plain Witchcrast; and see, he is falling into a Fit as soon as he comes into his Presence.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You will perceive more anon.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: My Wife is a Whore, I'll touch her no more: For why? She rides on a Switch with Touchstone the Witch.— Where is he?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How the Profane Fiend, within, calls upon my Name; but, I say still, I will stop my Ears with Mandragora.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Did you hear that, Gentleman? That very Word's enough to raise a Spirit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: See how he foams!

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: And swells:

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: These Proofs are undeniable.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Be not concern'd, Sir, we'll prove it Forgery, and recover upon it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Most palpable! A meer Conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, the Person is Bewitch'd, that is most certain; but by no skill of mine, as I hope to be Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Buz, Buz, Buz.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: I pray observe him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: She comes with a Needle, and puts it in,
He pulls it out, and puts in a Pin.— Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: O Barbarous Wretch! How the poor Creature's Tortured? Come, hold a Candle to the Wizard's Fingers ends, and that will give him ease.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I will clear my Conscience before a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You do not tumble enough.

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Alas, how he is vexed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: 'Tis past all Contradiction.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: He shews the taking of Tabaco, with which the Fiend is so delighted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now he fancies himself Cast away, and Swimming for his Life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: How the Devil can Act!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O Terrible! What Swelling is that upon his Belly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Any Rising upon his Belly? Keep it down, keep it down.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: 'Tis meer Confederacy, you shall recover from Mr. Wolf too abundantly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Meer Jugling.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I tell you, Sirs, I am astonish'd: There must be a Witch amongst us.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Oi Moi Kakodemon, Kai Tris Kakodemon, Kai Pentakis, Kai Mariakis.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Now he Curses me in Greek: Mr. Bramble, I would I were fairly off this Business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: What Paper is that flown out of his Throat.

body.p: To Alderman Touchstone, from Shoreditch. This is the Third time I am with Child by you; yet to be forgetful to supply your Disconsolate Servant,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This must be the Devil, I shall be undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: How, Mr. Alderman, Witch and Whore-master too?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Now, Sir, the Cheat appears most plainly; I'll take it on my Oath, I saw your Wife give him that Paper.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And you saw it too, Mr. Bramble.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Not distinctly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But you can swear it.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: For half Costs. 'Tis most apparent, I will swear to it.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Your Gossip will see you double, to come over to us.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Enough. These Proofs are pregnant,— Mr. Alderman, you are the Witch,— You ratify?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I will manage the poor Lunatick's Cause, though I do it gratis: We will make your Worship an Example.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Oh Hypocrite! Dost thou forsake me too?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My Life for yours, Sir, stand to't.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And so I will; I am convinc'd now, 'tis all Roguery: Davie, go call Mr. Justice Snappal hither presently. My Indignation is kindled, and I will prosecute them to the Death.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This will not do: I will try the Experiment more.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But how if a Jury should give this Business against, and get Condemn'd for a Wizard? I would this Concern were well off, and all Friends again.
sp.stage: Quick-silver re-enters with the Hide upon him. Mrs. Touchstone shrieks out. Security rises frighted, Quick-silver and he run over one another.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Mischief on your Cowards Heart; all's spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why gave you me no Warning?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I hope you are satisfy'd, you see the Implements, here is his Mouse, and here his Bellows and false Belly; ha! ha! ha! We thank you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I told you, Sir, 'twas all a Cheat; we will recover swingingly from 'em.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I defie you, Mr. Bramble. I am o'er-joy'd to find my Honour safe: Well, it was a witty Practice, and I forgive them all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: Why, that's well said, they were resolv'd to make you Merry.
sp.stage: Enter Girfred, Mildred, Wynnifred, Syndefie, and Mrs. Bramble.
sp.p: Come, Sir, your Pity must descend here too; you see they have all done Penance: Come, Lady-child, you must ask your Father Blessing.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Not unless he desires it, Mrs. Touchstone.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: She has Spirit for an Empress: Tell her, Wife, I desire her, to desire my Pardon.— Come, Son Golding, I must desire you too, to intercede to me, on the Offenders Behalf.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: I'll undertake for that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: O my mad Run-away, to forsake me in the first Month! But it was like a Man of the Times.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Ah Wynny! Bunting, Gold-fineh, to break from your Cage, and leave your Constant Cue.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then, as I take it, here is my Lawyer that has been busie on all sides, is fairly bauk'd on all sides; and my Usurer-Bawd prov'd a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Even my Learned Gossip, here, is in the same Premunire.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We therefore beg of your Worship, and Mr. Deputy here, to see these two Ladies peaceably re-settled with their Owners.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How will you advise in this point, my Learn'd Councel?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: We have a Precedent for't in the wise Cato.

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: But on Condition of Christian Liberty; and that we be lockt up no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. T.
sp.p: All Reason in the World for it; and besides, Gentlemen, it is your Interest; for as you came to be Cuckolds by locking your Wives up: for ought I know, you may be Uncuckolded by giving them their freedom.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
That's very well said too.— Come, Sirs, we must all Sup together, and be Friends. Run afore Davie, and buy up the whole
Market.— Mr. Wolf, you must be our Guest too: We'll summon the City Musick to us, with a Consort of the whole Neighbourhood.
To joyn their Voices in the highest Pitch,
And sing loud Thanks ---- That I am found No Witch.

lg.l: WE have shewn an Alderman no Conjurer. (were?
‛ Nouns, crys Pit-Bully, Who e'er thought there
Have Patience, Sirs, next bout we'll shew, if luck hold,
What's strange indeed, ----- an Alderman no Cuckold:
A Privilege for serious Play too great,
But Farce has Privilege, Farce, our last Retreat:
For as kept Misses, when their Keepers tire,
With some new slight, revive the pall'd desire;
So Poets banking th' old Roads of the Stage,
Bring Farce to tickle up th' Enervate Age:
Poets, and Whores, you equally shou'd dread;
A-like infections, where their Venom's spread.
What's Poetry, but 〈◊〉 Clap i'th' Head?
Yet Clapt Gallant sometimes gets Sound agen,
No Cure for Gonorrhoea of the Pen
The Parallel holds further, as I guess,
There's Whores for Need, and Whores for Wantonness;
So there's Sale Poetry, Poetry of Lord,
Worth just as much, as his sweet Lordships Word.
One Word more from the Authour, I must say,
He once hit Farce, whate'er he has done to day.
He then had Strength, you should have charg'd him then;
But Criticks are a sort of Country-men,
Their Valour of the true Militia-Strein;
Who from the fighting Foe, like Lightning fled,
But come like Thunder back, to Maul the Dead.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
